0.text: Emotional exhaustion is often the result of prolonged stress and a lack of resources for recovery. Regular breaks, hobbies and support from family and friends can significantly help to cope with this state.
0.fact: In a Gallup survey of employees, 23% of respondents reported feeling burned out always or very often, and another 44% said they felt burned out sometimes.

1.text: Physical activity and a balanced diet play a key role in maintaining energy levels and preventing persistent fatigue.
1.fact: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, has repeatedly spoken about the importance of proper rest and sleep for maintaining productivity and preventing fatigue. He says that getting at least eight hours of sleep helps him stay energetic and effective.

2.text: Planning your morning can help reduce stress and increase motivation. Simple routines like light exercise, meditation or reading can make mornings more pleasant and manageable.
2.fact: Tim Cook, the CEO of Apple, is known for waking up very early (around 4:30 a.m.). At the same time, he emphasizes the importance of good night sleep and regular physical activity for maintaining energy and motivation.

3.text: Training in emotional intelligence can help managers and employees understand each other better and work more effectively together. This may include courses on active listening, conflict management and developing empathy.
3.fact: Emotional intelligence (EQ) plays a key role in team management and workplace success. Research by TalentSmart shows that 90% of top performers have a high level of emotional intelligence.

4.text: Empathy and genuine personal attention from leaders can significantly reduce staff turnover. A Harvard Business Review study showed that employees who feel supported and noticed by their managers are four times less likely to leave the company.
4.fact: Elon Musk, the founder of Tesla and SpaceX, is known for his demanding and intense leadership style. Some employees have noted that this approach can feel harsh and impersonal, which contributes to stress and burnout in teams.

5.text: Psychological practices such as meditation, yoga and mindfulness techniques can help maintain emotional balance and increase energy levels.
5.fact: Richard Branson, the founder of the Virgin Group, is known for his enthusiasm and high energy. He often stresses the importance of a positive attitude and energy for success in both business and personal life, and says that optimism helps him overcome difficulties and inspire his team.

6.text: Training in conflict management usually includes developing skills in active listening, empathy and the ability to find compromise. Courses and workshops on these skills can be very useful at all levels of an organisation.
6.fact: Effective conflict resolution can significantly boost team productivity. A Harvard Business Review study showed that companies that manage conflict well have 30% higher performance.

7.text: Psychotherapy and consultations with a psychologist can be very helpful for those who experience feelings of oppression and apathy. Cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) is often used to address depression and burnout.

8.text: Feedback and recognition from colleagues and managers can strengthen the sense that one’s work matters. Regular acknowledgement of achievements supports higher motivation and job satisfaction.
8.fact: Job satisfaction is linked to improved performance. According to Harvard Business Review, employees who see the value of their work are 21% more productive and 22% more profitable for the company.

9.text: Neuroscience research shows that when people feel empathy, the same brain areas can be activated as during physical pain. This means emotional connection can be deep and very significant.
9.fact: Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, is known for his philosophy of “radical transparency” and honesty at work. He believes that openly discussing problems and mistakes helps improve relationships within the team and increases its effectiveness.

10.text: Studies indicate that maintaining a balance between work and personal life can greatly reduce stress and help prevent hardening and cynicism. Companies like Basecamp actively promote shorter working weeks and minimal overtime to improve employee well-being.
10.fact: Martin Seligman’s work in positive psychology shows that cultivating traits such as gratitude and optimism can significantly improve emotional well-being and reduce bitterness and resentment.

11.text: Research in positive psychology, including the work of Martin Seligman, shows that optimism and belief in the future can significantly improve quality of life and support goal achievement.
11.fact: In some countries, such as Sweden, there is the concept of “fika” — a regular break for coffee and informal conversation, which helps reduce stress and prevent burnout.

12.text: Engaging in hobbies or personal projects can provide a sense of satisfaction and help balance negative emotions related to work. Well-known entrepreneurs such as Richard Branson actively pursue personal projects that bring them joy and inspiration.

13.text: Jack Ma, the founder of a major internet company, was once a supporter of the “996” work model (9 a.m. to 9 p.m., six days a week). Later he acknowledged that such a regime can be harmful both for employees’ health and for the organisation as a whole.

14.text: Research suggests that burnout can be “contagious” in work teams, spreading from one employee to another through shared atmosphere, emotional tone and behaviour patterns.

15.text: The idea of a “digital detox” — a period of completely disconnecting from electronic devices — is becoming increasingly popular as a way to reduce information overload and prevent burnout.
15.fact: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, is known for taking long breaks and stepping away from social networks. He believes such pauses help him preserve energy and stay inspired for his work.

16.text: The concept of “psychological safety” in teams was developed by Harvard Business School professor Amy Edmondson. She argues that it is a key factor in team effectiveness.
16.fact: According to the Society for Human Resource Management, 61% of employees say that trust between workers and management is very important for job satisfaction.

17.text: The concept of “flow”, described by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, explains a state of complete immersion in an activity, accompanied by a sense of energy and enjoyment.
17.fact: Google has used the “20% time” rule, allowing employees to spend one-fifth of their working time on projects of their own choice, which increases creativity and engagement.

18.text: According to Pew Research Center, 30% of Americans see their job as a calling, 44% as a career and 24% simply as a way to earn a living.
18.fact: TOMS Shoes uses a “One for One” model, donating a pair of shoes to someone in need for every pair sold, which gives employees a sense that their work brings real benefit.

19.text: The Japanese concept of “ikigai” describes the intersection of what you love, what you are good at, what the world needs and what you can be paid for. It is considered a key to finding satisfaction in work.
19.fact: Muhammad Yunus, Nobel Peace Prize laureate, founded Grameen Bank to provide microloans to people living in poverty. He often speaks about the importance of “social business” for addressing global problems.

20.text: In Sweden, some companies are experimenting with a six-hour working day to increase productivity and reduce burnout. Early results show higher energy and motivation among employees.
20.fact: Oprah Winfrey admitted in 2008 that she experienced burnout and a loss of interest in her show, which influenced her decision to end it a few years later.

21.text: Google offers its employees the “Search Inside Yourself” course, which teaches mindfulness and emotional intelligence skills to better manage stress and emotions at work.
21.fact: According to the World Health Organization, depression and anxiety cost the global economy about $1 trillion a year in lost productivity.

22.text: The term “emotional vampirism” in psychology describes people who drain the energy of those around them, often shifting their problems and emotional burden onto others.
22.fact: Some companies, such as Zappos, have implemented “holacracy” — a management model where responsibility is distributed among self-organising teams instead of being concentrated in the hands of managers.

low.text: Your current level of productivity is stable and within a comfortable range. You may sometimes feel tired, but overall you manage to maintain a healthy rhythm and a balance between work and rest. This helps you preserve energy, motivation and emotional well-being. Keep treating yourself with care and supporting the balance you have already found.
low.title: High productivity

middle.text: Your productivity has decreased somewhat, possibly due to increased workload or insufficient recovery. This is not yet critical: you still manage to work and find satisfaction in your tasks. However, it may be helpful now to pay more attention to the balance between work and rest so that you can maintain stable energy and emotional resilience.
middle.title: Reduced productivity

high.text: Your internal resources may be significantly depleted. You may have been under high pressure for a long time or doing tasks that give you little sense of meaning or satisfaction. This state can affect your motivation, mood and sense of purpose at work. It is especially important now to slow down, restore your strength and take care of your well-being. Support, rest and revising your workload can help you regain energy and stability.
high.title: Close to burnout

text: Do you often feel tired, lose interest in work or struggle to restore your energy?
This test can help you see whether signs of emotional exhaustion have appeared and how well your workload and rest are balanced.
Your answers will show how your inner resources feel right now and whether it might be worth making changes to support your productivity and well-being.
